I was still in a sci-fi mood after my last read but also wanted something on the shorter side. This was awesome, introducing an immediately likeable lead while packing in cool world-building, creepy tension, and exciting action scenes, all within about 150 pages.

I immediately clicked with the main character's vibe, a deadly for-hire security robot that's secretly overridden its company's ability to control it, primarily using that freedom to quietly binge-watch television dramas during its downtime. The writing has a lot of fun with character's mindset, with the robot mildly annoyed by and uncomfortable around the humans it still genuinely wants to protect.

Highly enjoyable! I'll certainly come back for more.

It's a simple plot and the entire action is described from the perspective of a bored robot tasked with caring for a group of scientists on an unexplored planet. Befriedigend!

In dieser Buchreihe ist der Technobabble eher im IT-Bereich angesiedelt und auch da reicht ein halbwegs oberfl√§chliches Verst√§ndnis davon, wie ein Code oder ein Netzwerk grunds√§tzlich funktionieren, um folgen zu k√∂nnen. Ich bin Historikerin, nicht ITlerin ‚Äì wenn ich das schaffe, schafft ihr das auch! Ich habe dank der Murderbot-Reihe zum ersten Mal verstanden, warum Leute sowas gerne lesen. Es war gar nicht anstrengend, sondern absolut m√ºhelos und aber ich hatte gleichzeitig das Gef√ºhl, total *smort* zu sein und alles voll zu durchschauen. Wieder: SO! Befriedrigend!

Ich liebe es, dass das Aussehen der Personen recht sp√§rlich beschrieben wird. Selbst von unserer Hauptfigur SecUnit erfahren wir im Verlauf der B√§nde nur vage Informationen zum √Ñu√üeren, abseits von ‚Äûin langen Klamotten siehts wie ein Mensch mit Dataport im Nacken aus‚Äú. Das gelingt in anderen B√ºchern nicht so gut, aber hier werden die Figuren √ºber ihr Verhalten, ihre Art zu sprechen und ihre Beziehungen untereinander so gut charakterisiert, dass das Aussehen so weit in den Hintergrund tritt, dass es tats√§chlich so egal ist, wie es sein sollte. Davon abgesehen lese ich ohnehin nicht gern lange Beschreibungen vom Aussehen, weil ich insbesondere Frisuren und Klamotten auch einfach nicht sehr interessant finde. Urban Fantasy und Romance sind voll von solchen Beschreibungen und es k√∂nnte mir nicht egaler sein, welche Jeans die Figur heute tr√§gt. date:
Martha Wells' "All Systems Red" introduces readers to Murderbot, a security unit that has hacked its governor module to gain autonomy. Despite its newfound freedom, Murderbot prefers to binge-watch media and avoid human interaction. However, it's stuck with a team of scientists on a survey mission on a distant planet. The story is told from Murderbot's cynical and introverted point of view, offering a unique perspective on the interactions between humans and AI. As the team explores the planet, they discover evidence of a previous, failed expedition and soon realize they are not alone.

The character development in "All Systems Red" is one of the strongest aspects of the novella. Murderbot is a fascinating and relatable protagonist, despite being an AI construct. Its internal monologue is filled with sarcasm, anxiety, and a surprising amount of empathy. The human characters are also well-drawn, each with their own distinct personalities and motivations. The relationship between Murderbot and the scientists evolves throughout the story, as they gradually come to trust and rely on each other. One of the major plot twists involves the revelation that the previous expedition was deliberately sabotaged, leading to a deadly confrontation with a rival corporation.

The tone of "All Systems Red" is a blend of action, humor, and introspection. Wells expertly balances the fast-paced plot with moments of quiet reflection, allowing readers to delve into Murderbot's complex inner world. The novella is filled with witty banter and sarcastic observations, providing plenty of laughs along the way. However, it also explores deeper themes about identity, freedom, and the nature of humanity.

Thematically, "All Systems Red" explores the question of what it means to be human, even for a non-human entity. Murderbot's struggle to understand its own emotions and motivations is a central theme of the story. The novella also touches on issues of corporate greed, environmental exploitation, and the ethics of artificial intelligence. Ultimately, "All Systems Red" is a story about finding connection and purpose in a hostile universe.

In conclusion, "All Systems Red" is a thrilling and thought-provoking novella that offers a fresh take on the science fiction genre. Martha Wells has created a memorable protagonist in Murderbot, and the story is filled with action, humor, and heart. For readers who enjoy "All Systems Red," I recommend "A Fire Upon the Deep" by Vernor Vinge, which also features complex AI characters and epic space battles, and "The Martian" by Andy Weir, which combines scientific accuracy with a compelling survival story.

While some might balk at neurodivergence representation in a robot, android, or cybernetic organism, the author is able to make a machine seem the most human, charming and relatable of all the characters in the book by showcasing the machine's own idiosyncrasies within a cast of diverse characters. It became uncannily easy to understand the machine's thought processes and choices and root for the seemingly cold, distant machine designed to murder.
Turns out the metal assassin you're flying with isn't calculating how to murder you, but disassociating and trying to watch their stories on the work hour.

This was a witty, fast-paced, intriguing, and action packed sci-fi story that was able to trust the audiences with their characters and plot without any filler, extraneous exposition, or dizzying world building.

An infinitesimal, personal complaint about the audiobook...almost wished the reader was British. Hearing an American voice say "solicitor" when referring to lawyers and legal aides took me out of the story MUCH easier than it should have. date:
Martha Wells somehow pulls off razor-sharp action, genuine emotional depth, and laugh-out-loud internal monologue in a novella that moves like a knife fight. Murderbot‚Äôs voice is iconic‚Äîdry, self-aware, prickly, and unexpectedly tender. It‚Äôs a masterclass in character work: you believe every snarky aside and every flicker of reluctant care.

What really elevates this to five stars is how much it says with so little page count. Themes of autonomy, consent, trauma, and personhood are woven in effortlessly. No speeches, no bloat, just clean, efficient storytelling.

I came for the action. I stayed for the existential dread, the found-family vibes, and the deeply relatable desire to avoid eye contact forever.

Murderbot internal dialogue:

I have to write a review for my own book?
Really?

Great‚Ä¶

This was not in my original contract. I don‚Äôt even know why I‚Äôm doing this. I would prefer almost anything else. Reformatting my media storage. Staring at a wall while running diagnostics. Dismembering my own hands - except that wouldn‚Äôt actually stop me from writing the review and then I‚Äôd still have to do it without hands, which feels inefficient.

Let me summarize The Murderbot Diaries for you:
When I could be watching an episode of The Rise and Fall of Sanctuary Moon, I keep having to save people from the problems they brought upon themselves.
The series is basically that situation. On repeat.

It‚Äôs entertaining,familiar and somehow I‚Äôm the most humane character in the story. Or so the humans say. Reviewing each book separately doesn‚Äôt make much sense to them anyway. Their brains can‚Äôt process the series as individual units. What they remember is the feeling‚Äîa similar emotional state repeating across short novellas.

We assess the threat. (I assess the threat)
We execute the plan. (In three long corporate cycles.)
We move on.
And yes, most of the time, the threat is human behavior.

Then it‚Äôs over. Which is unfortunate, because now we have free time again and people might try to talk to me.

Now, if you‚Äôll excuse me‚Ä¶
I have 124 new episodes to watch.

Reading All Systems Red felt like slipping into the mind of someone who‚Äôs already given up on being understood. Murderbot‚Äôs voice is sardonic, numb, and strangely heartbreaking ‚Äî a creature built for violence, wired for obedience, yet quietly desperate to disappear into the comforting static of its media feeds. The isolation hits hardest: it moves through the world surrounded by people it‚Äôs meant to protect, yet it never believes it belongs beside them. That loneliness, wrapped in humor sharp enough to border on self-defense, makes the story feel less like sci-fi adventure and more like a confession from someone who never asked to exist.

What lingers isn‚Äôt the danger the characters face but the way Murderbot constantly assumes the worst of itself. Every time it steps between humans and harm, there‚Äôs this sense of weary inevitability ‚Äî like it‚Äôs bracing for the moment its usefulness runs out. Its internal monologue reads like someone trying to shrink out of their own story, terrified of being seen, yet unable to stop caring in the small, reluctant ways that hurt the most. Even when the plot accelerates into tense survival, that low thrum of self-loathing never really fades; it just hides under the action beats.

By the end, the book doesn‚Äôt offer comfort so much as a grim acknowledgment of what it means to keep going when connection feels dangerous and identity feels like a wound. The story is short, almost brutally so, and it leaves you with the sense that Murderbot‚Äôs journey is far from healing ‚Äî it‚Äôs merely the first step of someone who knows freedom won‚Äôt magically make them whole. And maybe that‚Äôs what makes this little novella so quietly devastating: beneath the armor, the algorithms, and the dry humor, Murderbot feels painfully human in its desire to stay unseen‚Ä¶ and its inability to stop caring anyway.

date:
They done murdered my bot. A security robot designed for killing hacks its own restrictions and does the least amount of work possible while watching soap operas. This time murder bot is on a planet with some researchers excavating and solving a murder mystery of sorts.

Positives: I liked the subtle comedy in this and obviously the premise is the best part. "the concept" of a killer robot just switching over and only caring about soap operas is pretty funny and played to fair effect here. I think Martha potentially going for a portrayal of autism through main character which is a cool way to do it but could be a little tricky given they are not fully human idk. Any autistic people, I would love to hear your thoughts

Negatives: book was maybe a tad too short where the mystery did not feel all the way fleshed out, but I understand given the nature of this series to be a large collection of small little adventures. Murderbot felt pretty flat which yes they are robot but at the same time felt like author was just running the same route ad nauseam.

PS: Faizi had his tea and Cookie get together today it was quite nice. That guy Matthew who is friends with Erin is quite a hoot.
